data.text:
Louisiana Citizens Policyholders will receive a rate reduction and bad faith claims against Louisiana Citizens will be limited to the policy's limit if Legislature Acts Sam Karlin continues his reporting of the Louisiana legislative session with instant updates. "Customers of Louisiana’s insurer of last resort, Citizens, may soon get a small break in their property insurance premiums, if lawmakers agree to legislation that would suspend the 10% surcharge for customers in the coastal part of the state. Republican leaders earlier in the session dismissed the idea of providing a break on Citizens premiums. But they agreed Tuesday to amendments on a bill by Sen. Kirk Talbot, R-River Ridge, to suspend the higher premiums for Citizens customers entirely in a dozen coastal parishes. Most of Citizens' policies are concentrated in the coastal zone. Customers in the rest of the state would pay 5% over the private market, down from 10% in current law." "The bill would also limit the amount of damages people can get when they sue Citizens. Talbot hoped to ban all bad-faith penalties for Citizens, but agreed to a compromise that limits the damages to the policy limit." The limitation of bad faith penalties for Louisiana Citizens is a step in the right direction. Hopefully, this progress can be expanded upon.

Bad Faith: The violation of Florida Statutes governing the timely and proper adjustment practices of insurance claims. Typically, bad faith can include unwarranted delay or denial of insurance benefits, unfair or deceptive practices, and misrepresentations of fact. Depending on the magnitude of the bad faith, Florida Statutes allow for the recovery of extra-contractual damages (damages beyond the terms of the insurance policy) and/or punitive damages. The Hon’ble Supreme Court recently dismissed the appeals filed by insurance companies against a Judgment of Hon’ble NCDRC vide which the NCDRC had directed the Insurance companies to pay the sum as per the Fire Perils insurance policies to the insured Cold Storage from the date of repudiation along with interest: The Hon’ble NCDRC, in its judgment, dealt with important and recurring issues like: 1. Whether Insurance Claim is payable when there is a case of double insurance; 2. Whether Insurance Claim is payable when the stock insured does not belong to the Insured; 3. Whether the insurance company can deny payment of claim on the basis of “Goods held in Trust” are not covered under the policy; The Cold Storage/Complainant before the NCDRC as well as before the SC was represented by Senior Advocate Arvind Nayar along-with other advocates. Attaching the Judgment passed by the Hon’ble Supreme Court and the Hon'ble NCDRC for the benefit of readers.
